apache-ant-1.6.0/src/main/org/apache/tools/ant/UnknownElement.java:            +
" - You have misspelt '" + elementName + "'." + lSep

'spelt' is also correct (and presumably used by Brtis and Aussies). Take a look:

http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=spelt

creator: stevel@apache.org
text:
yes, misspelt is correct in many locales, especially en-uk. Unless we
standardise on en-us across the entire docs, I'd say leave as is. At the very
least, it introduces readers to alternate spellings of words.


Summary: misspelt is not misspelt :)

creator: gus.heck@olin.edu
text:
Technically misspelt may be correct, but most elementary school teachers in US
(and thus most people in the US) will put a big red X on misspelt. Do other
locals mark misspelled as wrong? I think the question is which spelling variant
will cause the the most readers to think that we passed 3rd grade :) ?

I believe the point is "why should the US be given special treatment regarding 
documentation to a package developed and used by people around the world?"  
We're lucky enough that the documentation is written in English at all, much 
less the English Miss Grundy taught to Archie, Jughead et al...
creator: mbenson@apache.org
gus.heck@olin.edu
text:
Oh for goodness sake re-read my comment. If misspelt is marked correct and
misspelled marked wrong in many other locations I am perfectly fine with
misspelt. If misspelled is right everywhere, and mispelt wrong in some places I
think it should be changed. 

This isn't about your feelings of injustice that the US is big right now and
happens to drive standards in directions that annoy you, it's about making Ant
appeal to the broadest audience possible. 

If the community as a whole wants to damage Ant to strike out at the US, it is
perfectly fine I suppose, they have a right to do that, but personally I think
we should put Ant first. If misspelled is offensive or stupid looking in some
areas then go with misspelt by all means, if not it should read "misspelled."

creator: mbenson@apache.org
text:
Calm down, there...  Firstly, I entertain neither political agendas 
nor "feelings of injustice" about much of anything.  I fully appreciate the 
position of the US in innovation, and I consider it my good fortune that the 
language around which the constructs of most leading programming languages are 
built is my own native tongue.  I also happen to take somewhat irrational 
offense to the various misspellings I encounter, and have done so from 
childhood.  I do, however, always try to be gracious on a personal level (at 
least considering the preferences of others), and I have tendency to play 
devil's advocate as well.  I can appreciate your point of "if 'misspelt' is 
correct 90% of the time, but 'misspelled' is correct 95% of the time, 
choose 'misspelled'."  Not having these numbers at hand, however, this quasi-
misspelling registers very low on the priority scale, from my perspective.

creator: gus.heck@olin.edu
text:
I'm saying that I would be extremly supprised if it isn't wrong in most of the
US. I suspect the US is a lot more than 10% of our user base. The only question
(still unanswered) is whether or not en-uk or some other large user base
considers misspelled wrong. If so, dead issue, leave it as is as we can't really
win either way, if not we should fix it IMHO.

creator: scohen@apache.org
text:
This thread has provided me with a fair bit of amusement for the past week.  Calm down, guys.  
It's FUNNY! 
 
Personally, I think the different spellings and other language managing are one of the charming 
aspects of working on an international project.  Haven't we all seen spellings of words that end 
in -ise instead of -ize?  Does anyone remember the "Demoroniser"? 
 
This would, IMHO not even be an issue except for the context.  Misspellings would not even 
be noticed anywhere, but this is different and humorous precisely because of the meaning of 
this word. 
 
Anybody who would reconsider their decision to use Ant on this basis needs to be 
"demoronised", IMHO.  
 
Lighten up.

There is no i18n policy in Ant; it is left up to whoever writes the code and
docs to choose which particular subset of english to use. If you want to add
code which uses 'color' and 'visualize' as words, go for it :)

At the same time, we dont want to offend people by gratingly irritating
spellings which may be correct in some locale, but not others. 

So, if people really want to replace misspelt (which looks fine to me) with
misspelled (which to my eyes looks like sheeps, mouses, runned or thinked), then
 the correct solution is not to try and convert to another locale, but come up
with a phrasing that is locale neutral. 

i.e "you cannot spell "+elementName

Of course, that introduces other cultural issues to with computers criticising
their users...
creator: stevel@apache.org

text:
I think the firestorm has died down...
My reason for contributing to a project is to improve it.
Some contributions are functional.  My spelling suggestion was more cosmetic
than functional.  I wasn't aware that different regions of the world have
different spellings for "spelled" or "misspelled".  I'm sure there are grammar
differences around the world too.  I can make spelling and grammar contributions
for only the region for which I am an expert, namely U.S. English.  Given that
Ant is not produced by/for that region, I will have to refrain from commenting
on aspects that look wrong to me.
